title: Maker of Demons
author: Matthew J Elliott
filename: 216 - Maker of Demons - Matthew J Elliott_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — BRIDGE
FX: PRE-RECORDED FANFARE.

When people speak of this day in a hundred years, they shall look upon it as the day on which two races were blessed with the soft phrase of peace. For too many years, our fleet drifted through space, where hope is coldest and despair best fits. But deliverance came in an unexpected form, when a blue box materialised onboard The Duke of Milan. That is why today, this day of days, we honour those who set us on a true course, the Doctor and Mel!
FX: CROWD OF ABOUT A HUNDRED APPLAUDS.

Not only did they find a new world for us to inhabit, but one containing a new and sustainable source of energy. And when paradise seemed within our grasp, we came to realise that this unnamed world was already inhabited, by the subterranean race we now know are called the Mogera. Once again, the Doctor came to our aid. In honour of our new-found co-operation, the Mogera and I have agreed to bestow upon this planet the name “Prosper.” What’s past is prologue, the seeds of time have this day been planted!
FX: THE CROWD GOES WILD, CHEERING AND APPLAUDING.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 3
SCENE 2: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — ANTEROOM
FX: THE DOCTOR IS PLAYING THE SPOONS.
Not the spoons, Doctor!
We'll be on in a minute - I thought the colonists might appreciate a little entertainment.
Don’t you think they’ve been through enough?
Oh, very well.
FX: HE STOPS PLAYING.
You know, I still can’t believe we’re actually on a spaceship, and not some ocean-going galleon.
Really, Mel?
If it weren’t for the fact that I look out of the portholes and see stars...
A galleon in space - what a fanciful notion.
You must admit, there is something strange about a wood- panelled spaceship.
Yes, you’ve not yet found every room in the TARDIS, have you?
It’s not just The Duke of Milan itself, it’s the people, too - the Elizabethan fashions, those collars, the way they talk...
Remind me to tell you about the Minyans and the Anethans.
What does that mean?
The tides of time wash in as well as out, Mel.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 4
So everything comes back again? Fashions, architecture, everything?
Everything. Except for loom bands - they were just a one-off.
FX: A DOOR SLIDES OPEN AUTOMATICALLY.
(OFF-MIC) .. to present to you all now, the Doctor and Mel!
Ah, we're on! Come along.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 3: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — BRIDGE (CONTINUOUS)
FX: THE DOCTOR AND MEL WALK OUT OVER A WOODEN FLOOR TO MUCH
APPLAUSE.
Thank you, thank you. Oh my goodness, what a lot of you there are.
And many more in the ships following us, Doctor. This ceremony is being simulcast to every one of them.
No need to stand on ceremony for us, you know.
He doesn’t usually like to hang around for the celebrations after the job’s done. Personally, I love it.
It was mostly good luck, you know.
Luck, and a decent collection of maps from the TARDIS’ interstellar cartography room.
I really don’t understand the need for all this ceremony.
(HUSHED) Quiet, Doctor! Why can’t you just learn to accept what you deserve?
FX: GONZALO PRODUCES THE TREATY.
I have in my hand a piece of paper...
Ah, that brings back memories.
. a pact between our race and the Mogera. Their leader has already placed his- his mark on it. And I am pleased to add my Signature...
FX: THE SCRATCHING OF A QUILL PEN.
Peace and prosperity!
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 6
FX: THE CROWD CHEERS AGAIN.
Hear, hear!
Doctor, some words!
Oh, I’m not sure that’s a good idea. He tends to get a bit tongue-tied.
Nonsense, Mel, I can talk the back legs off a hankie.
The Doctor’s very happy for both humans and Mogera, and he wishes you all the best for the future.
FX: THE CROWD APPLAUD.
Couldn’t have put it better myself.
I know.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 4: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — CORRIDOR
FX: FADE UP. DOCTOR, MEL AND GONZALO APPROACH THE TARDIS.
You surely haven’t grown bored with us already, Doctor?
I could never grow bored of an adventure without fatalities. But we really must be on our way in my TARDIS.
The Doctor worries that she might start to pine.
FX: THEY STOP WALKING.
Well, here we are.
It’s been a pleasure, Captain Gonzalo.
And an honour for us all.
FX: THE DOCTOR TURNS THE KEY IN THE TARDIS LOCK.
What do you say to a holiday, Mel?
Oh, yes, Doctor! I haven’t been to Earth in ages.
FX: THE TARDIS DOOR OPENS AND THEY ENTER.
Oh, and.. Look after that treaty, Captain.
FX: GONZALO HOLDS UP THE TREATY.
My dear Doctor, this treaty is the purest treasure mortal times
afford.
FX: TARDIS DOOR CLOSES, FOLLOWED BY THE DEMATERIALISATION
SOUND.
(SIGHS) I thought they’d never go.
FX: HE TEARS THE TREATY IN TWO. MUSIC: OPENING THEME.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 8
SCENE 5: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: VARIOUS MECHANICAL ITEMS ARE DROPPED TO THE FLOOR, WITH
BUZZING FROM THE SONIC SCREWDRIVER.
(TO MEL) So then what happened?
(DISTRACTED) Well, I said to poor old Tesla, “Nikola, if you don’t dismantle the transmitter, the Vardans will just invade again.”
Doctor, that’s not the story I was telling at all!
Oh, wasn’t it?
No! — What are you doing under the console, anyway?
The TARDIS’s “Check Engine” light has been on for the last four hundred years. I’m determined to get to the bottom of it.
FX: A CRYSTALLINE OBJECT SMASHES.
Oh. Well, I’m sure that wasn’t important. — So what story were you telling, Mel? The were-tarantulas of Vyga 3?
I was telling Ace about the treaty between the human colonists and the Mogera on Prosper.
Well, that’s a good one, too.
The Doctor’s story sounded better.
I thought you might prefer to hear about a time when nobody died and nothing exploded.
You don’t really know me at all, do you?
What on Earth made you think of that, Mel?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 9
Because you said we were headed back there!
Did I? Does that sound like the sort of thing I’d be likely to say?
You said it was one of your items on your bucket list.
Really?
FX: HE PRODUCES THE LIST.
Oh yes, there it is, just after “duet with Frank Sinatra”.
Which you did last week.
We were lucky to get out of that one with our lives.
Yes, he wasn’t as good a sport as I’d hoped.
Well, he did like to do things his way.
I should probably cross off “host a game show” and “find out what happened to the dinosaurs”.
FX: HE CRUMPLES UP THE LIST.
And I might save “box with Joe Frazier” for a later incarnation.
But, look, we are actually going to this place- what’d you say it was called again?
Ace, weren’t you listening either?
Not really. Sorry, Mel.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 10
SCENE 6: INT. ARMY VEHICLE
FX: INTERIOR OF THE VEHICLE, ITS WHEELS TRAVELLING OVER ROUGH
GROUND, AND ITS ENGINES EMITTING A HIGH-PITCHED ENERGY NOISE. THE VEHICLE IS TRAVELLING RELATIVELY SLOWLY. A REPETITIVE SONAR
THROUGHOUT.
Sector Thirteen clear. Tell the old man he was right — they’re letting us off lightly today. Right, it’s two glasses past the mid-season, just a couple more sectors, and we’ll call it-
FX: THROUGH STATIC, THE FAINT TARDIS MATERIALISATION NOISE.
What the hel11...?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 11
SCENE 7: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
The fleet was on its way to Dido when it was hit by solar storms.
Now, Dido I have heard of.
A planet not without features of interest.
FX: SOMETHING ON THE TARDIS CONSOLE SPARKS.
Ow!
They were low on fuel and lower on rations, so the Doctor put them on a new course, a planet so unknown it didn’t even have a name. But it turned out there was a problem.
Someone else was already living there — the Mogera, right?
Whose territory just happened to be on top of the largest source of Doctorium on the planet.
Obviously, it wasn’t called that before the Doctor discovered Tes
That would have been something of a coincidence.
I do know this story. Loads like it, anyway. The natives have something, the settlers want it, and they’1l kill as many natives as they like to get their hands on it.
Except that on this occasion, we were able to reach an accord before a single shot was fired.
Believe me, Ace, it would’ve been a bloodbath — the Mogera weren’t exactly equipped for fighting. Imagine Moley from The Wind in the Willows.
Can’t. Never read it.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 12
Oh. Well, that’s how they struck me, anyway. They were only about so high, and very timid. I just wanted to cuddle them to bits.
Ugh.
They weren’t unappealing, certainly.
FX: THE DOCTOR FLICKS SOME SWITCHES ON THE CONSOLE.
Hang on, you still haven’t told me what this Doctorium thing 18:5
The best-kept secret in the Universe — prima materia.
Prima what?
An abiotic energy source produced in the bowels of the planet.
From what I understood, it could power just about anything — it’s produced naturally at the planet’s core and it never runs out.
Hopefully. Let’s find out.
We've arrived? I didn’t hear anything.
Yeah, what happened to the “dummmm” noise?
Uh...
FX: HE RUMMAGES THROUGH PIECES OF EQUIPMENT.
I think it must come from one of these.
But we are actually where we’re meant to be? On Prosper?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 13
One hundred years to the day since our last visit.
“To the day”? So in other words we’re gonna be, like, a million years out either way?
Nonsense! You’re never tardy in a TARDIS, that’s what I always say.
I have literally never heard you say that.
Me neither.
Well, you’re not always here. I might’ve said it to Polly, or Tegan, or Sharon...
You’ve never mentioned a Sharon before.
Everyone has at least one Sharon in their life.
I think he might have a point there.
FX: HE OPENS THE DOOR AND THEY HEAD FOR THE EXIT.
And I think we’1ll find both humans and Mogera are enjoying a golden age- (TRAILS OFF AS HE SEES OUTSIDE)
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 14
SCENE 8: EXT. STREETS OF PROSPER (CONTINUOUS)
FX: CHILL WIND BLOWS. THE DOCTOR, ACE AND MEL STOP SHORT IN
THEIR TRACKS.
. Oh.
Your idea of a golden age and mine are pretty different, Professor.
This is wrong.
Very wrong.
FX: HE CLOSES THE TARDIS DOOR.
You reckon, do you? I think The Specials wrote a song about this place.
What happened here?
FX: THEY MOVE THROUGH THE STREETS.
I don’t know, Mel.
I was sort of expecting rocket packs and golden skyscrapers from the way you were bigging this place up.
Take it from me, rocket packs aren’t always a positive sign.
And crashed spaceships are?
They haven’t crashed. These must be the colony ships. They just landed them here and turned them into cities.
Except there’s no “they.” I don’t see or hear anyone. And no birds.
There weren’t any in the first place.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 15
Doctor — this isn’t because of anything we did... is it?
I’m asking myself the same question.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 9: INT. ARMY VEHICLE
FX: VEHICLE GRADUALLY PICKING UP SPEED. MIRANDA IS TALKING
OVER THE RADIO WITH ALONSO.
Sector Fourteen, just a few minutes ago. We detected the noise.
(D; OVER RADIO) What sort of noise?
Not a noise. The noise.
(D) The noi-? (REALISATION) Oh my prophetic soul, it’s finally happened!
Just as you predicted.
(D) I didn’t exactly predict it, but it was always a possibility. How far out are you?
We can have him back at The Duke within half an hour.
(D) Wonderful!
FX: SMALL ALARM SIGNAL.
Wait! There’s a problem. We’re detecting tremors.
(D) Oh no. It’s too soon! Too soon!
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 10: EXT. STREETS OF PROSPER
FX: ACE STARTS TO WANDER OFF-MIC.
(DEPARTING) Look, I was joking before when I said we might be out a few million years, but we could be on the wrong planet, couldn’t we? I mean, it’s not like aren’t a few to choose from.
I’m afraid this is definitely Prosper.
And these are definitely the colonists’ ships.
What’s left of them.
You’re right about that, Doctor. Some of them look like they’ve been bombed.
(OFF-MIC) I don’t know about bombed, Mel. These seem more like claw marks.
FX: A LOW RUMBLE, RISING IN VOLUME UNDER MEL’S LINE.
I don’t remember anything on Prosper capable of doing that.
Perhaps there’s been an- Do you hear that?
(OFF-MIC) Yeah, what is that?
Ace, get back here!
FX: A LARGE MASS OF EARTH EXPLODES, SPREADING STONES AND DIRT.
(OFF-MIC) And what is that?!
FX: CLAWING AT THE GROUND, A HUGE BEING CLIMBS UP AND SETS TWO
FEET ON THE GROUND.
SNUFFLES AND GROWLS
It’s like some kind of armour-plated.. ogre! It just came up from the ground!
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 18
(OFF-MIC) He doesn’t seem friendly!
The growling might just be their way of communicating!
A SHRIEK LIKE A WILD BOAR
FX: THE THING SWISHES ITS CLAWS ABOUT.
(OFF-MIC) Definitely not friendly!
I think we know what made those claw-marks now! Ace, try to get out of its way!
(OFF-MIC) Thanks, keep those good ideas coming!
FX: TWO MORE EXPLOSIONS OF EARTH, AND TWO MORE THINGS EMERGE.
ALSO SHRIEKING
More of them!
We’re going to have to run for it!
FX: A VIOLENT WIND WHIPS UP, GROWING EVER MORE FURIOUS. THE
VEHICLE SPEEDS IN AND PULLS UP.
BEGIN TO WHIMPER IN ABJECT TERROR
Now what? What’s going on?
I don’t know, I can’t see for the dust! (CALLING) Ace, can you make it to the TARDIS?
Ace? Ace, where are you, we can’t see you!
FX: THE DOOR OF THE ARMY VEHICLE SLIDES OPEN AND A FLURRY OF
FIRE STRIKES THREE TARGETS (THE LASER FIRE IS OF THE SAME
AS THE ENGINE POWERING THE VEHICLE).
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 19
ALL SHRIEK IN PAIN
Who’s shooting?
(SLIGHTLY OFF-MIC) Get in!
What?
(SLIGHTLY OFF-MIC) Both of you, get into the transport!
Do as she says!
We don’t even know who she is!
True, but she’s not shooting at us, she’s shooting at them!
(SLIGHTLY OFF-MIC) Hurry!
Wait, we have a friend!
(SLIGHTLY OFF-MIC) I’m glad to hear it, now inside!
Come on, Mel!
FX: THE TWO CLAMBER INSIDE A METAL INTERIOR.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 11: INT. ARMY VEHICLE (CONTINUOUS)
FX: DOOR SLIDES SHUT.
Driver — go, go!
FX: AND THE VEHICLE BUILDS UP POWER AND SHOOTS OFF.
We can’t just go, we need to wait for Ace!
It really is you, isn’t it? A century later, and you look exactly the same.
That makes a change. Look, I really must insist that you turn this vehicle around-
I’m afraid that’s impossible, Doctor. You’re needed back at The Duke.
The Duke?
The Duke of Milan — our headquarters.
Why are you still using your old ships? Why haven’t you built anything?
We’ve been a little busy, Mel. It is Mel, isn’t it?
Yes.
They said you were time-travellers. I don’t think I ever believed it. It’s not usually nice, being wrong — today, I’m glad I was.
Happy to be of assistance.
Driver, contact The Duke, tell them we’ve picked up our visitors, and that apparently there’s a third, still wandering the streets.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 21
Please! We need our friend.
Forgive me, Doctor, but the Minister of Fate needs you more.
Minister of Fate? Is that another ship?
I hope so, Mel, because otherwise it sounds quite ominous.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL)
SCENE 12: EXT. STREETS OF PROSPER
FX: THE GALE IS DYING DOWN.
Doctor? Mel? What happened? Where’d you go?
FX: SHE WANDERS AROUND.
Anyone about? Great!
FX: SHE HAMMERS ON METAL.
Anybody in there? You decent? Hello? Hello! Look, have gone now, it’s safe to let me in. I’m- nice. probably talking to myself.
Page 22
those things And I’m
FX: THE RUMBLE OF A MOGERA APPROACHING UNDERGROUND, AS HEARD
EARLIER.
Uh-oh. I know that noise. Not hanging round this time! Which
way’s the TARDIS?
FX: SHE RUNS.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 13: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — LABS
FX: A SERIES OF ELECTRONIC NOISES IN BG OF CONSTANTLY
MACHINERY.
Miranda, everyone here on The Duke's talking about the Doctor. It’s not true, is it?
(D; OVER RADIO) He’s sitting right next to me right now, Juno. Is that true enough for you?
The actual Doctor, with the hat and the umbrella?
(D) Believe me, I’m finding it hard enough to believe and I’m actually looking at him.
There goes my paper on the impossibility of time travel.
(D) When would you have got around to writing it?
Good point. And what about the other one, Mel?
(D) She’s here, too. And apparently there’s another one, a female.
(D; OFF) Her name is Ace!
She’s lost in Sector Fourteen.
(D) Is she, now? That’s not good. Do you think they know how not good it is?
(D) If they didn’t before, they do now.
No room for tact in science. When you get back here, bring them down to the lab. I want to see the legendary Doctor for myself.
(D) Attending.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 24
FX: THE RADIO SHUTS OFF.
(A LONG, DEEP SIGH) Doctor...
FX: JUNO PUSHES BACK HER CHAIR, AND WALKS OFF (OVER WOODEN
FLOORS, LIKE ALL OTHER LOCATIONS ON THE DUKE).
(DEPARTING) Nobody touch anything on my workstation, I'll be right back!
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 14: INT. CALIBAN’S UNDERGROUND LAIR.
FX: CALIBAN SPEAKS THROUGH AN ELECTRONIC SYNTHESIZER, THOUGH
HE’S STILL RECOGNIZABLY A MOGERA.

All Burrow-Brothers, take heed! A stranger wanders the streets of the human district — she is not of The Duke of Milan, her clothing and her ways are different. Her presence on our world is a sign! She must be brought to me! Our destiny depends upon it! The brave warrior who brings her here will have earned himself a promotion — away from the main battle!
SHRIEK ENTHUSIASTICALLY
FX: THEY STAMP THEIR FEET AS THEY SHRIEK.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 26
SCENE 15: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — ENTRY BAY.
FX: THE DOCTOR, MEL AND MIRANDA HURRY INTO THE SHIP. ALONSO
APPROACHES.
(APPROACHING) Miranda! Juno told me everything!
FX: THE BAY DOOR CLOSES AUTOMATICALLY.
Hard to believe, I know. But here’s the proof.
I think they’re talking about us, Doctor.
Indeed I am, child!
The Minister of Fate, I presume?
Alonso, please! The Doctor and Mel. Well. The statues don’t do either of you justice.
There are statues?

There were statues. I think we may still have some pictures of them, but I’m afraid nostalgia hasn’t really been a priority. As I’m sure you gathered, we don’t have a great deal of time for reminiscing.
Or much of anything, apart from surviving.
Miranda, child, I’ve noticed that your driver Adrian has worked four consecutive tours. Go after him and tell him he’s excused the next two tours, would you?
Attending.
FX: SHE MARCHES AWAY.
Mr Alonso — Minister — we have a friend, who- Forgive me, have we met?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 27
Had I been so honoured, Doctor, I would surely have remembered LE.
I recognised you straight away! The features, the voice - even the ruff could be the same. You look just like Gonzalo - captain of The Duke of Milan!
My illustrious ancestor. The man who helped turn Prosper from an optimistic dream into a paradise.
Except it didn’t stay a paradise, did it?
About eight months. But it was a glorious eight months, by all accounts.
Is that when they invaded?
Invaded?
Those creatures we saw — those armour-plated trolls.
Ogres.
Ogres.
We've seen them, Alonso. They almost tore our friend to pieces with those massive claws.
You baffle me, both of you. Prosper hasn’t been invaded.
But we thought the only intelligent beings native to this planet were the Mogera.
And you thought correctly.
Well?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 28
Those creatures who attacked you out on the streets were the
Mogera.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 29
SCENE 16: EXT. STREETS OF PROSPER
FX: ACE IS RUNNING.

The TARDIS! There you are..! (FX: STOPS RUNNING) You, my friend, are the most beautiful thing I’ve seen since Teen Beat printed that picture of Johnny Chess with his shirt off- No, forget that, you’re just the most beautiful, the most fabulous, the most welcoming...
FX: SHE PULLS THE DOOR HANDLE. IT WON’T OPEN.
Uh... At least you would be, if I hadn’t left my key inside!
FX: SHE HAMMERS ON THE TARDIS DOOR.

Aw, come on! (DRAWS BREATH) OK... Look: the Doctor’s always saying you’re more than just a machine, that you’re a living thing? So, you know me, right? We’ve been around each other for a while now. So why not just let me in? Hm? C’mon. Show me some love.
FX: SHE TRIES THE HANDLE AGAIN, THEN GOES NUTS ON THE DOOR
IT DOESN’T WORK.
You’ve always hated me, haven’t you? Admit it! Mel’s your favourite, I know, I can tell! I bet she could just snap her fingers, and you’d let her walk right in, wouldn’t you? Well, that’s just fine!
FX: ONE LAST KICK AT THE DOOR.
I’1ll catch up with the Doctor. Even if I have to- run.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 17: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — BRIDGE
FX: INSTRUMENTATION NOISES.
Ace? Our histories don’t include mention of an Ace. Is shea new addition to your crew?
Actually, I am. It’s complicated.
Time out of joint, eh? You don’t have to explain.
Oh, thank goodness.
I’ll see if anyone can be spared to look for your friend. In the meantime, there’s much to discuss.
There certainly is. How did all this happen, Alonso?
And when?
Now, I don’t want you to blame yourselves, either of you. It’s not entirely your fault.
Our fault?
We had no reason to believe the Doctorium was at all harmful. It certainly had no effect on human physiology.
The Doctorium...?
It altered the Mogera — physically and mentally. They became much, much larger, pathologically aggressive. This all came to pass not long after you abandoned us.
We didn’t really think of it as abandoning you.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 31
Nevertheless, for the last hundred years, the Mogera have been raiding our territory, killing our people and stealing our technology.
And the metal from your ships — I assume that’s what they fashion their armour from.
Quite correct. Apart from anything else, it’s extremely ill- mannered.
But why are they doing it?
You'd have to ask Caliban, their leader. But I couldn’t in all good conscience, recommend that you do so. He’s rather angry with you, Doctor.
Alonso, I ran tests on the Doctorium, I was sure it was safe-
Yes, yes. That’s all in the past. And what’s past is prologue.
So I hear.
Now you’ve returned to us, an entirely new volume in Prosper’s history is about to be written, just as we thought we’d almost reached the end of the tale.
Things are really that bad, then?

My dear Mel, another year, and there won’t be enough of us left to make a human settlement on this world sustainable. Most of the survivors are here, in The Duke — there are still a few scattered bands of people out there. We try to protect them as best we can, but...
I can’t believe the Mogera are capable of doing something like that.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 32

But you saw it with your own eyes. The Duke of Milan's super- thick hull protects most of the survivors, but we can’t last much longer. And though it pains me to inform you, it’s almost certain that the girl Ace is dead also.
No!
Hell is empty, Doctor, and all the devils are here.
And it seems I created those devils.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 33
SCENE 18: EXT. STREETS OF PROSPER
FX: STEPHANO STAGGERS FOR A FEW STEPS.
BREATHES WITH DIFFICULTY
(OFF-MIC) Hey, you! Any shelter round here?
(HOARSE) Get away!
(OFF-MIC) What?
(HOARSE) Get away from here! Get aw-
FX: HE FALLS TO HIS KNEES, THEN COLLAPSES COMPLETELY.
(OFF-MIC) Hey!
FX: SHE RUNS TOWARD STEPHANO.
It’s all right, I’m here.
Noooo... (HE SOBS) Why couldn’t you leave me alone? Now we’re both dead!
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 34
SCENE 19: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — BRIDGE
FX: CALIBAN’S SPEECH IS BEING BROADCAST ON A SCREEN.

(D) Our Burrow-Fathers were duped! Duped by the humans, duped by the being known as the Doctor! He tricked us into mining for his precious Doctorium, knowing it would poison us, knowing it would make us into monsters! Knowing that-
Pause it.
FX: THE RECORDING IS PAUSED.
Scurvy monster, this Caliban, isn’t he?
Terrifying!
He’s the Mogera’s equivalent of a war hero. But one man’s terrorist, you know...
FX: A DOOR SLIDES OPEN AUTOMATICALLY AND JUNO ENTERS.
Minister, I thought you ought to know our last attempts to block Setebos were unsuccessful, I’m afraid. Somehow he’s managed to hack his way back in.
The Devil take his fingers!
Who’s Setebos?
A minor irritation, no more than a distraction for our Chief Mage here. Oh, Juno here is head of the League of Technogicians. Juno, the Doctor and Mel.
Delighted. You’re some sort of scientific adviser, I take it?
I do more than advise, Doctor. It’s my job to find new ways of dealing with the mess you left us in a century ago.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 35
I was just showing our guests footage of the self-styled “General” Caliban.
I was just wondering, why does he have that thing on his neck?

GONZALO: When people speak of this day in a hundred years, they shall look upon it as the day on which two races were blessed with the soft phrase of peace. For too many years, our fleet drifted through space, where hope is coldest and despair best fits. But deliverance came in an unexpected form, when a blue box materialised onboard The Duke of Milan. That is why today, this day of days, we honour those who set us on a true course, the Doctor and Mel!
GONZALO: Not only did they find a new world for us to inhabit, but one containing a new and sustainable source of energy. And when paradise seemed within our grasp, we came to realise that this unnamed world was already inhabited, by the subterranean race we now know are called the Mogera. Once again, the Doctor came to our aid. ALONSO: Ace? Our histories don’t include mention of an Ace. Is shea new addition to your crew?
MEL: Actually, I am. It’s complicated.
ALONSO: Time out of joint, eh? You don’t have to explain.
MEL: Oh, thank goodness.
ALONSO: I’ll see if anyone can be spared to look for your friend. In the meantime, there’s much to discuss.
DOCTOR: There certainly is. How did all this happen, Alonso?
MEL: And when?
ALONSO: Now, I don’t want you to blame yourselves, either of you. It’s not entirely your fault.
MEL: Our fault?
ALONSO: We had no reason to believe the Doctorium was at all harmful. It certainly had no effect on human physiology.
DOCTOR: The Doctorium...?
ALONSO: It altered the Mogera — physically and mentally. They became much, much larger, pathologically aggressive. This all came to pass not long after you abandoned us.
MEL: We didn’t really think of it as abandoning you.
MEL: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 31
ALONSO: Nevertheless, for the last hundred years, the Mogera have been raiding our territory, killing our people and stealing our technology.
DOCTOR: And the metal from your ships — I assume that’s what they fashion their armour from.
ALONSO: Quite correct. Apart from anything else, it’s extremely ill- mannered.
MEL: But why are they doing it?
ALONSO: You'd have to ask Caliban, their leader. But I couldn’t in all good conscience, recommend that you do so. He’s rather angry with you, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Alonso, I ran tests on the Doctorium, I was sure it was safe-
ALONSO: Yes, yes. That’s all in the past. And what’s past is prologue.
DOCTOR: So I hear.
ALONSO: Now you’ve returned to us, an entirely new volume in Prosper’s history is about to be written, just as we thought we’d almost reached the end of the tale.
MEL: Things are really that bad, then?
ALONSO: My dear Mel, another year, and there won’t be enough of us left to make a human settlement on this world sustainable. Most of the survivors are here, in The Duke — there are still a few scattered bands of people out there. We try to protect them as best we can, but...
MEL: I can’t believe the Mogera are capable of doing something like that.
MEL: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 32
ALONSO: But you saw it with your own eyes. The Duke of Milan's super- thick hull protects most of the survivors, but we can’t last much longer. And though it pains me to inform you, it’s almost certain that the girl Ace is dead also.
MEL: No!
ALONSO: Hell is empty, Doctor, and all the devils are here.
DOCTOR: And it seems I created those devils.
DOCTOR: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 33
DOCTOR: SCENE 18: EXT. STREETS OF PROSPER
ACE: (OFF-MIC) Hey, you! Any shelter round here?
STEPHANO: (HOARSE) Get away!
ACE: (OFF-MIC) What?
STEPHANO: (HOARSE) Get away from here! Get aw-
ACE: (OFF-MIC) Hey!
ACE: It’s all right, I’m here.
STEPHANO: Noooo... (HE SOBS) Why couldn’t you leave me alone? Now we’re both dead!
STEPHANO: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 34
STEPHANO: SCENE 19: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — BRIDGE
CALIBAN: (D) Our Burrow-Fathers were duped! Duped by the humans, duped by the being known as the Doctor! He tricked us into mining for his precious Doctorium, knowing it would poison us, knowing it would make us into monsters! Knowing that-
ALONSO: Pause it.
ALONSO: Scurvy monster, this Caliban, isn’t he?
MEL: Terrifying!
ALONSO: He’s the Mogera’s equivalent of a war hero. But one man’s terrorist, you know...
JUNO: Minister, I thought you ought to know our last attempts to block Setebos were unsuccessful, I’m afraid. Somehow he’s managed to hack his way back in.
ALONSO: The Devil take his fingers!
MEL: Who’s Setebos?
ALONSO: A minor irritation, no more than a distraction for our Chief Mage here. Oh, Juno here is head of the League of Technogicians. Juno, the Doctor and Mel.
DOCTOR: Delighted. You’re some sort of scientific adviser, I take it?
JUNO: I do more than advise, Doctor. It’s my job to find new ways of dealing with the mess you left us in a century ago.
JUNO: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 35
ALONSO: I was just showing our guests footage of the self-styled “General” Caliban.
MEL: I was just wondering, why does he have that thing on his neck?
JUNO: Voice synthesizer of some sort. He was wounded by our troops shortly before he rose to power about, um, fifteen years ago. (A BEAT) Thereabouts. To him, the synthesizer’s a symbol of our human cruelty.
ALONSO: As is everything about the Mogera, particularly their strength and aggression.
DOCTOR: Because I persuaded them to mine the Doctorium.
JUNO: Which transformed them into the thing they hate the most. Although they also hate us for making them hate themselves.
ALONSO: Succinctly put, Juno.
MEL: I’m sorry, but they can’t be the same creatures, they just can’t!
JUNO: Look at this.
JUNO: That’s a Mogera, taken shortly after the colony ships arrived.
MEL: Awww...
JUNO: And this is one of the few images we’ve been able to get of them as they are now. You see? Teeth become fangs, nails become talons. The only thing that hasn’t increased, apparently, is their brain capacity, which is capable of processing only resentment.
JUNO: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 36
DOCTOR: I don’t suppose anybody’s tried negotiation?
ALONSO: The one person who did took that picture - moments before his flesh was shredded by the claws of the Mogera. Since then, we've relied on the League of Technogicians to provide us with effective weaponry.
JUNO: Not simply weaponry, but tracking systems, too. It’s hard to predict where your enemy will strike when they travel at speed underground.
MEL: We saw three of them claw their way to the surface, just before a storm whipped up, and then Miranda appeared and scared them off with- well, it sort of looked like a wizard’s stick.
JUNO: One of these, you mean? Catch.
MEL: It is a wizard’s stick!
DOCTOR: The staff’s powered by Doctorium, I take it?
JUNO: Fresh cells go in here, you see?
DOCTOR: And with this you can manipulate climactic conditions?
ALONSO: On a very small scale, yes.
DOCTOR: Small?
JUNO: And over a very short range. The Mogera retain an inbred fear of extreme weather. But it’s no more than a defensive measure — eventually, they’1l overcome it and gradually slash their way in here.
DOCTOR: How many have died?
DOCTOR: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 37
JUNO: Excuse me, Doctor?
DOCTOR: How many people have died since the Mogera mutated?
ALONSO: I don’t know that records are kept any more, but... several million.
MEL: Million...!
JUNO: Including my daughter.
DOCTOR: Juno, I’m so sorry.
JUNO: Don’t be. I, for one, am very grateful for the opportunity to thank you in person, Doctor, for everything you’ve done for us.
JUNO: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 38
JUNO: SCENE 20: EXT. STREETS OF PROSPER
ACE: You still with me, mate? Come back to me.
ACE: They did this to you, those hairy things in the armour, they tore you up like this? Is your home anywhere round here?
STEPHANO: Home...
ACE: Yeah, home, you know?
STEPHANO: Family.
ACE: Family, that’s right. I’m going to get you back to your family. What’s your name?
STEPHANO: Stephano.
ACE: Alright, Stephano, we’re getting out of here — so long as you can tell me where we go.
STEPHANO: My family...
ACE: You’re going to see your family soon enough.
STEPHANO: I think so, too. (SPLUTTERS) Take this.
ACE: What is it, some sort of gun?
STEPHANO: Take it.
ACE: I dunno, I have a friend who sort of has a thing against guns.
ACE: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 39
STEPHANO: Take — it!
STEPHANO: UNDERGROUND, AS HEARD EARLIER.
ACE: Fine, fine, I’1ll take it. Now do you think you can walk? Stephano? Take my hand, let me help you up. Come on, come on, open your eyes!
ACE: Open your eyes! (REALISATION; HE’S DEAD) Damn. I’m sorry, Stephano. I’m so... sorry.
ACE: SURFACE.
ACE: Not again! Stay back! I’ve got a gun, and I’m not afraid to use at!
ACE: All right, I am sort of afraid to use it, but I’1ll still use it, so back off, OK?
ACE: I warned you!
ACE: A REGULAR GUN. THE FOUR PROJECTILES FLY FROM THE WEAPON AND
SPLAT: AGAINST TALPA LIKE PELLETS FROM A PAINT GUN.
ACE: Oh, no way! I hit you every time! Not fair! All right, no further, or I empty this thing into you.
ACE: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 40
ACE: Uh-oh.
TALPA: END OF PART ONE
TALPA: MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 41

elements.text: PART TWO
I warned you!
FX: SHE FIRES FOUR TIMES. IT’S NOT AN ENERGY WEAPON, NOR IS IT
A REGULAR GUN. THE FOUR PROJECTILES FLY FROM THE WEAPON AND
AGAINST TALPA LIKE PELLETS FROM A PAINT GUN.
SHRIEKS AGAIN
Oh, no way! I hit you every time! Not fair! All right, no further, or I empty this thing into you.
FX: SHE PULLS THE TRIGGER SEVERAL TIMES. IT JUST CLICKS.
Uh-oh.
ROARS...
SCENE 21: EXT. STREETS OF PROSPER (CONTINUOUS )

(BEGINS SNORTING FRANTICALLY AND REPEATEDLY, THEN SHRIEKING AS THOUGH IN TERRIBLE PAIN - HE’S UNDERGOING A PAINFUL TRANSFORMATION. FINALLY, HE IS PANTING IN EXHAUSTION) Thank you so much! That feels a lot better.
Huh???
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 42
SCENE 22: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — BRIDGE
FX: DOORS SLIDE OPEN. MEL MARCHES IN.
Ah, Mel — is the Doctor quite satisfied with the facilities?
I want to talk to you, Alonso!
Please, Mel, call me Minister when I’m on duty. I can make an exception for you, but I can’t risk the spread of informality. Dignity is an important aspect of my position.
FX: SQUEAKY WHEELS APPROACH.
You want anything off the trolley? Custards? Ale?
Not now, man!
FX: THE WHEELS RETREAT.
All right, Minister, what have you done about finding Ace?
I was afraid we were going to end up having this conversation.
I take it that means “nothing,” then?
Because no-one qualified can be spared. Don’t think I don’t know your anguish; in fact, I think it’s fair to say I have experienced that pain a hundredfold.
Ace doesn’t know how much trouble she’s in. She has no idea that the Mogera have mutated — we promised her a paradise.
My feted ancestor promised his entire colony fleet the same. Now we’re on the brink of extinction.
There’s nothing I can do to convince you, is there?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 43
If only the gift of persuasion could solve all our difficulties, Mel, Prosper would be a brighter place for your presence. Sadly, it cannot.
Fine! That’s just fine!
FX: SHE MARCHES OFF.
Mel, where are you going?
(DEPARTING) You have your responsibilities, Minister, I’ve got mine!
FX: THE DOORS OPEN AND CLOSE AS SHE LEAVES.
(SLIGHTLY-OFF MIC) Trolley’s still here if you want anything. The custards are getting a bit dribbly.
Look, just go away, will you!
FX: WITH AGONISING SLOWNESS, TRINK PUSHES THE TROLLEY OUT.
WHISTLES ‘GREENSLEEVES’ AS HE GOES
FX: THE DOORS OPEN, AND TRINK LEAVES, THE DOORS SHUTTING
HIM AGAIN.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 44
SCENE 23: EXT. STREETS OF PROSPER
What happened to you?
You did. If you hadn’t shot me there’d have been no going back.
You can talk. Why can you talk?
Why can you?
No, no, no, we’re not playing that game. When I saw you before-
We’ve never met before.
When I saw more of whatever you are before-
Mogera. We’re the Mogera.
Mogera? I have got Wind in the Willows all wrong. Well, your mates were pretty feral, and you weren’t all that friendly a minute ago, either. That’s why I had to shoot you.
I agree.
But you’re not dead.
Because that’s not a gun. You might as well throw it away, it’s empty now.
Fair enough.
FX: SHE DROPS IT ON THE GROUND.
If it’s not a gun, what is it?
Vaccine delivery system. Without it, I’d be- well, even more of a monster.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 45
Right. OK. So we’re good? I’1ll be on my way, then.
No. You’re not going anywhere unless it’s with me.
I thought you said you were grateful!
For what you did, not why you did it. You thought that was a
weapon, and you were going to kill me.
FX: TALPA’S RIFLE HUMS AS THOUGH POWERING UP.
But this is a weapon. And you’re wanted by General Caliban! Now
come on!
FX: ACE SLIPS AS THOUGH PUSHED.
Hey!
Move!
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 46
SCENE 24: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — AFT QUARTERS
FX: DOCTOR AND JUNO WALK UP AND DOWN AN ECHOEY EMPTY SPACE.
The aft quarters are at your disposal, Doctor.
Very nice. Very roomy. Reminds me of the time Dodo and I spent aboard The Golden Hinde.
This area was used for entertainments in earlier times - when there were more of us.
Entertainments?
Dances, plays.
Tell me, Juno, have you ever staged The Tempest?
The what?
Doesn’t matter. Doubtless someone liked the names, sometime in the past. (A THOUGHT) Unless I tell Will about all this, sometime in the future?
The Minister is very anxious that you should be as comfortable as possible while you work.
Why, thank you. Work at what?
Obviously, finding a solution to our present parlous situation. I don’t see the point, personally, but he thinks you might be able to think outside the box.
Depends on the box. There’s one I think particularly well inside of.
The legendary TARDIS. You’re anxious to leave us, then?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 47
I’m more anxious about my friend Ace. And speaking of friends,
where’s Mel?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 48
SCENE 25: EXT. IMMEDIATELY OUTSIDE DUKE OF MILAN.
FX: MEL REPEATEDLY FLIPS A DOOR HANDLE.
Please, one of you be unlocked! I never have this problem with the TARDIS.
FX: MIRANDA APPROACHES OVER DUSTY GROUND.
(APPROACHING) Mel, what are you doing?
What does it look like I’m doing?
Well, it looks like you’re trying to steal one of our transports.
Only if I can get into one.
Even if you could, would you know how to drive it?
Trust me, I’m a very fast learner.
I believe you. But I can’t allow it.
What are you going to do, Miranda? Shoot me, or put me in the middle of a tornado?
I don’t want to have to do either.
Then just give me the keys, or whatever it takes to unlock one of these vehicles.
This is about Ace, isn’t it?
No, Miranda, I just thought I’d take in some of the local beauty spots. Of course it’s about Ace!
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 49
You’re can’t face what’s out there alone, Mel, and no-one else can be spared.
So I’m told. But you don’t seem to be doing anything.
Except trying to protect you. Even this close to The Duke, we're not safe. Come back inside.

When I come back inside, it’1ll be with Ace. And before you say it, yes, I’m sure you’ve lost far more people than I have or ever will, but you must understand what it means to want to keep someone safe.
You’re going to get us both killed, you know that, don’t you?
FX: DOOR HANDLE IS FLIPPED ONCE MORE. A BLEEP OF RESPONSE AND
THE DOOR SLIDES OPEN.
Thank you.
FX: ANOTHER VEHICLE APPROACHES AT SPEED.
Thank me when we come back alive. If we come back.
Miranda, what’s that? Is it the Mogera?
Mogera don’t need vehicles, they travel underground. It’s one of ours! No-one should be out at this time!
It’s covered in claw marks!
And it’s not slowing down! — Mel, get out of the way!
FX: THE VEHICLE CRASHES INTO METAL HULL OF THE SHIP WITH A
CRUNCH.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 50
SCENE 26: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — LAB
I wanted you to join me in the lab, Doctor, because I think you should see just how dire our present situation is.
FX: AS SHE SPEAKS, SHE PRESSES A SEQUENCE OF BUTTONS. A PANEL
OPEN.
This is all there is?
These tanks represent our last reserves of Doctorium.
Whenever I hear that name, it’s like a knife through each of my hearts.
And an even bigger one through your ego, I suppose.
But surely this can’t be the last of it, Juno.
All that’s available to us. There are seams in our territory, but mining them is suicidally dangerous when you have a subterranean enemy.
FX: A SIREN SUDDENLY BLARES.
Now what?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 51
SCENE 27: EXT. IMMEDIATELY OUTSIDE DUKE OF MILAN.
FX: FLAMES FLICKER.
COUGHS
Mel, are you all right?
Thanks to you. Who was driving that thing?
That’s what I’d like to know! (COUGHS) Come on, whoever it is, we've got to get them out of there!
Careful, Miranda, it might- (COUGH) It might explode!
I think the worst has already happened.
FX: SAME BLEEP AS SHE FLIPS THE HANDLE AND SLIDES OPEN DOOR.
(SEES WHO’S INSIDE) Alonso!
FX: THE DOCTOR AND JUNO APPROACH AT A RUN.
(APPROACHING) Mel, Mel, are you safe?
We both are, but I don’t know if we can say the same about the driver.
Minister!
Someone help me get him out of there! And be careful with him — we don’t know the extent of his injuries.
He’s still breathing, he’s just unconscious.
SNORES
Not precisely, Mel. I think he’s asleep.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 52
SCENE 28: EXT. WASTES OF PROSPER
FX: MEL AND TALPA WALK OVER ROUGH TERRAIN.
You should know, that man we left back there — the one your mates ripped to shreds. Before he died, he told me his name.
Mm?
Stephano.
Humans all have funny names.
He had a family. Don’t you want to know if I have a family?
I’m not even really interested whether or not you have a name.
I do. It’s Ace.
Well, Ace, it’s going to be a long journey, since you lot can’t breathe underground.
Not easily, anyway.
So I’d appreciate a little quiet.
Well, that’s too bad, because I’d really like us to get to know each other.
You want me to feel bad about killing you?
Killing me? You said you were going to hand me over to some General.
I might not be able to stop myself.
I thought you were cured of the ‘roid rage.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 53
You saw other Mogera.
Just after I got here. If they’re what pass for tourist guides on Prosper, your customer service skills need a bit of work.
Were they wearing bandoliers?
Like a belt across their chest? Yeah. What’s that for, spare ammo?
It stores the vaccine we take when we’re away from the burrows. Four ampoules a day: a green one first, then three yellow ones during the day.
So why don’t you have one of these belts?
I lost it in a- skirmish.
Yeah, I’ve seen what happens to people who get caught in one of your “skirmishes.” But you’re fine now, right?
Only because you gave me a massive dose. When it’s run its course, I’ll revert. This time, there’1ll be no coming back for me. I’11 kill anything that moves.
Let me know when it’s happening, so I’11 know not to move.
If it helps at all-
It won’t.
The alien I was actually hoping to kill was the one who did this to us — a being called the Doctor.
What?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 54
SCENE 29: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — INFIRMARY
FX: CONSTANT BEEP OF A HEART MONITOR
It’s all rather embarrassing, really.
The physician tells me you managed to avoid breaking a single bone.
I should call it little short of miraculous.
What did you think you were doing out there?
The Doctor and Mel’s friend is on the streets somewhere. I was the only non-essential person available to look for her.
Since when is the Minister of Fate non-essential?
There’1l always be another, child.
Forgive me, but it was damn foolish.
Especially since the girl is almost certainly dead. Statistically speaking.
I don’t give a damn what your statistics say!
Mel, please. Alonso, I take it you didn’t see a trace of her?
I’m so sorry, Doctor. I was on my way back here to inform you, when my eyes grew wondrous heavy... I felt a good dullness, and I must have dozed off moments before the crash.
Your state of total relaxation saved your life.
One sees it in drunks and babies — not to imply that you’re either, of course.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 55
No, Doctor, I’m an old man — be not disturbed with my infirmity. But it seems for once, my advancing years have been of some use.
Not in finding Ace, they haven’t. Come on, Miranda.
I’m sorry, Mel, we've left it far too late. There’s no way I can permit anyone to leave The Duke.
Oh, I don’t believe this!
FX: MEL MARCHES OFF. AUTOMATIC DOORS OPEN AND CLOSE.
Mel!
Go after her, child.
Attending.
FX: SHE FOLLOWS. AUTOMATIC DOORS OPEN AND CLOSE.
Doctor, Juno’s probably told you already, I- I need you to do something for us.
If it’s to help you destroy the Mogera, Alonso, that’s something I can’t agree to.
Not that, never that. Just... find a way to bring this madness, this violence, to an end. Juno will work with you.
Oh, will she?
I accepted the title of Minister of Fate so many years ago because I wanted to carry on the work of my ancestors. Now I Simply want to put a stop to the killing. And I have no idea how to do that.
I’m responsible for everything that’s happened here.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 56
Agreed.
How can I do anything else but help you and the Mogera?
Thank you, Doctor. That’s all I ask.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 57
SCENE 30: EXT. WASTES OF PROSPER
FX: ACE AND TALPA ARE STILL MARCHING, BUT ACE IS DRAGGING HER
FEET.
It’s tiring, all this walking. Don’t you find it tiring? (NO REPLY) ‘Cos I do. (PAUSE) This is actually a pretty nice planet you’ve got here. A bit bleak, but I’ve seen a lot worse.
GRUNTS
Lovely sky. I like a nice sky, me. Just the right number of suns. Oh, look if we’re gonna talk, I’ve got to know your name.
Then we just won’t talk.
What’s your name?
(AFTER A PAUSE) Talpa.
OK, Talpa, I’m tired. I don’t have the legs of a massive, armour-plated rage-monster. I’m a human being, and I’m knackered.
Fine! (FX: HE STOPS ABRUPTLY, AS DOES ACE) We stop here for the night.
Is there any food? Every two or three days, I get hungry.
FX: HE PASSES HER A SMALL WRAPPED ITEM.
Survival rations.
FX: SHE UNWRAPS IT.
Do they taste as good as they look? (WITH A FULL MOUTH) Sadly, yeah, they do.
Anything else wrong?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 58
I could be warmer.
Then allow me.
FX: THE RIFLE WARMS UP.
Hey!
FX: THE RIFLE FIRES A QUICK BLAST AT THE SAME PITCH AS THE
ENGINES AND MIRANDA’S STAFF. FLAMES CRACKLE.
Tree stump’1l burn for hours.
FX: HE DROPS THE RIFLE.
Does your gun need to be that massive, or are you just making up for something?
It’s based on human technology, you tell me. And like every piece of technology on Prosper, it’s powered by Doctorium.
I thought you said that stuff was poisoning you. Why do you use it in all your weapons? Seems barmy to me.
Once the last of the humans are gone from this world, we’1ll block up the mines for good.
You know you could do that right now?
Not until we’ve taken vengeance on the ones who did this to us.
It wasn’t on purpose!
Your own people say it was!
Who? Who says that?
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 59
SCENE 31: INT. DUKE OF MILAN — LAB
FX: SETEBOS IS BROADCASTING OVER A RADIO, WITH INFREQUENT
DISTORTION AND INTERFERENCE.

How does one even put into words the method by which it is possible to overthrow those who have lied to us, held us in contempt, kept us in virtual slavery for generations? I speak in particular here of The Minister of Fate himself, he is the loathsome canker that lives in the sweetest bud. It is here already, my friends: Total martial law, total surveillance, total taxation, a revolution of criminality, and we have reached the key point where we have become acclimated to it. Let every eye negotiate for itself! It has emerged, and once the Mogera, the demons we have made, have been exterminated, the final phase is total domination, oh yes. Make no mistake, Prosper is a world of deceit and we have lost too many to this manufactured slaughter! [FROM THIS POINT ON, JUNO AND THE

TALK OVER HIS SPEECH WHICH CONTINUES AS FOLLOWS: I Say, let grief convert to anger! Blunt not the heart, enrage it! We have all become comfortable living under the heel of tyranny. I grant our Minister bloody, luxurious, avaricious, false, deceitful, malicious, smacking of every sin that has a name. The answer to defeating him and his pernicious League of Technogicians is to withdraw our consent at every level. Expose the system as fraudulent, don’t let these degenerate cultural oxymorons possess the power that rightfully belongs to you, the people. We will never back down! They are bringing us into bondage with huge chains, forged for us and our children, smiling at us all the time!]
Setebos. If you really want to be of any use, Doctor, you can find a way to shut him up.
Setebos — I believe I’ve heard that name before.
He’s a buffoon, a mutineer, constantly spouting nonsense about how we intentionally infected the Mogera with Doctorium as part of some open-eyed conspiracy that changes from week-to-week.
I’d be happy to assure him that wasn’t the case.

If you can find him. He’s somehow able to jump onto our frequencies and broadcast his deluded rambling to all our devices — possibly the Mogera’s too, for all I know. Audio only - he’s too much of a coward to show his face.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 60
And you can’t trace them back to the source?
If I could find him, I’d offer him a position with the League — once I’d finished supplanting some of his teeth.
Mel has a particular aptitude with computers, perhaps you should speak to her.
Always keen to dodge responsibility, aren’t you, Doctor? Is that the secret of your success?
I wouldn’t categorise what’s happened on Prosper a success.
Then we agree on something.
MAKER OF DEMONS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 61
SCENE 32: EXT. WASTES OF PROSPER
